items.description: River Stour and Smestow Brook in the Black Country and South Staffordshire

items.message:
Small, flashier rivers and streams may respond to heavy rainfall as a result of localised thunderstorms are forecast across England.  This message has been issued pre-emptively ahead of localised thunderstorms between 00:00 (midnight) on 01/08/24 and 06:00 on 02/08/24.  Given the unpredictable nature of thunderstorms, there is low confidence in the locations and impacts of rainfall at this point.  Areas most at risk are low lying agricultural land, roads and footpaths close to small rivers and streams.  Water levels could rise rapidly and potentially generate deep, fast flows.   
Thunderstorms are forecast over the next 24 hours, with low confidence over exact timing and locations.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 13:00 on 02/08/24, or as the situation changes.

The Flood Alert has now been removed. 
The thunderstorms and heavy rain have passed and no flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels have risen due to yesterday's heavy thunderstorms.  As a result low lying land and roads close to the rivers may be flooded, particularly on and around Water Lane and Haxted Road. Today is expected to remain largely dry with the chance of scattered showers this afternoon. We are clearing debris from weed screens and closely monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 18:00 on 02/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

This message will be updated by 13:00 on 02/08/24, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the Upper River Loddon as a result of yesterdays thunderstorms. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today 02/08/24, especially in the Longbridge Mill area.

Further rainfall, which may be heavy at times, is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 03/08/24, or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, although standing water and debris may remain.
There is no further rainfall forecast today, so we are unlikely to issue further alerts.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels have fallen after yesterday's heavy rain and thunderstorms.  Flooding from the Kidbrooke stream is no longer expected although some standing water may still remain. Today should be largely dry with scattered showers.  River levels are not expected to rise again but we a closely monitoring the situation and clearing debris from weed screens in the area.
